NORTH CAROLINA WINS DEBATE

Prov s No Match for Hopkins' Lacrosse
Team in Passing or Stick Work—
Score, 13-0—Silberstein, Bauernschmidt and Defandorf Star.

Combined Musical and Glee Clubs Render Attractive Program at C.E.Hall

Defeats the Hopkins Affirmative Team,
and the Washington and Lee
Negative Team.

The Rutgers lacrosse team
proved to be no match for the
Hopkins twelve, the latter scoring an easy victory last Saturday,
13 to. 0. The visitors' attack was
very poor, while their passing and
stickwork seemed equally bad.
They showed plenty of fight, however, and were always in the
game.
Silberstein, who took Stuart's
place, was the scoring star of the
game, with four goals to his
credit, while Defandorf and Bauernschmidt were not far 'behind
him, each .scoring three times.
"Bobby" Hoffman's work was
also particularly good, since he
stopped many rushes down the
field, which seemed sure to reach
the close ,defense.
During the first half, the Rutgers team made the play comparatively close, and only three scores
were made, by Hinrichs, Hoffman
and Silberstein: Hopkins started
the second period with a rush, and
scored continually, so that when
the smoke cleared away 10 markers had been, chalked up. The
home team used many.substitutes
(luring the latter part of the game,
but seemed to be able to score as
well as ever.
The Hopkins team showed a decided return to first-class form in
this game, and were far superior
to their opponents in passing and
teamwork, a department in which
Rutgers„was noticeably lacking.
As Rufiers . played a very close
game with Swarthmore last week,
Hopkins shiyind meet- with success
in her Inter-collegiate League
games. .
The brilliant vermilion jerseys
and stockings of the New Jersey
men made the game a •pretty one
to watch, while Feirer, Rutgers'
.chunky goal, furnished much
amusement by the speed and manner in which he got the ball away
from the net.

Before a disappointingly small
audience, the debating team of the
University of North Carolina was
awarded the victory over the
Washington and Lee representatives on Saturday evening in the
Civil Engineering Hall, by a
unanimous vote of.the five judges.
The subject for debate was: "A
system of universal military
training for young men should
be established by the United
States." The North Carolinians
supported the affirmative of this
question.
Daniel L. Grant, first affirmat ive speaker, pointed out the fact
that other great nations of the
world are increasing their armaments, and that therefore in order to retain her place as a leader and to secure herself against
future invasion,, _America must
adopt an effective method of constructing a powerful military machine.
Robert B. Gwynn,second affirmative speaker, presented a large
number of. historical instances to
show the inadequacy of the voluntary system of maintaining our,
armies. He also outlined a system of universal milit6ry training which, to his mind, would
prove most efficacious in the Unit-,
ed States. This system, according
to the figures ,whlch he presented,
would aptually cost less than the
maintenance of our present small
standing army.
Carl A.Voss, first speaker for
Washipton and Leç,jointed out
that -the affirmative mnst..Arst
prove that the voluntary system
of maintaining our armies has
some incurable and inherent defects, and then, in addition to
lit is, must show that the adoption
of a system of universal training
is the best method of establishing
an effective military organization.
lie then attempted to prove that
many defects of the present system had already been corrected,
and that the remaining defects
could likewise be remedied. Mr.
Poss delivered a well-prepared
e eh in a clear, convincing manlier.
Walter E. Smith, last speaker
for the negative, objected to the
universal military training plan
on the grounds that it would increase taxes, that it was through
this very system that Bismarck
had molded Germany into a highly militaristic nation, that military life is morally degrading,
and, finally, that America, in her

Cotillion Notice.

The Cotillion Board announces
that the last cotillion will be held
in the Civil Engineering Hall on
Saturday evening, May 15. Informal dancing will begin at 8.30
o'clock, and the regular program
of 16 dances will be in effect from
9 until 12, when the usual supper
will be served. Elaborate arrangements have been launched, which,
when completed, will make this
dance the social climax of the
season. Tickets may be obtained
for $3.00 from any member of the
Cotillion Board.

The concert given by the combined Johns Hopkins Orchestra
and Choral Society on April 27
was a marked success for the
Johns Hopkins Musical Association. The audience overflowed
the seating space, and many stood
throughout the entire performance.
A particularly interesting feature was the first appearance of
the Johns Hopkins Choral Society, which rendered admirably
"Hiawatha's Wedding Feast,"
from Coleridge-Taylor's famous
cantata. The ensemble tone was
of agreeable quality, and the technical difficulties of the work were
skilfully handled. Mr. Bochau is
to be congratulated upon the excellent results achieved in so
short a time with a new organization.
The orchestra first played two
movements from Beethoven's second symphony with surprising
facility and smoothness, and was
later heard in an arrangement of
Bruch's "Kol Nidrei" and Bendel's "Snow White." The cello
silo of this piece was presented
by Helen Broemer, accompanied
by Susan Haury.
The present membership of the
orchestra is 85, including professional musicians assisting for
this concert, and 80 per cent. of
the orchestra amateurs, among
them some graduates and undergraduate students of the University and members of the faculty,
and many well-known outside musicians, both men and women.
Those desiring to join the orchestra should make application
to Mr. Bochau at 304 East North
avenue.

Intelligence tests for freshmen
are rapily coming into vogue
among universities and colleges
throughout the country. Dartmouth freshmen recently took
these, and the results were as follows: The highest grade obtained
was 203 out of a possible 212. The
lowest grade was 70. The average for 636 students was 148.35.
The army and navy average for
these same tests was but 53.

BALTIMORE, MD,

MAY 3, 1920

The little affair of last week
was a fitting answer to the editorial in the issue of April 27.
The "Banquet Scene" was the
first sign of life which Hopkins
has displayed in quite a while,
but it shows that there is a little
spark still burning, and that it
can, upon occasion, flare up into
a regular flame.
Let us hope that the past outburst of "pep" will spread into
more appropriate channels—into
the backing up of the athletic and
non-athletic activities of the University. If such spirit were shown
more often, the populace of Baltimore would not be so surprised,
and other colleges would realize
that we have an undergraduate
student body which is interested
in the welfare of Hopkins.
The sole drawback to the whole
affair that THE NEWS-LETTER observed was the unfortunate'and,
for the most part, erroneous publicity which was accorded it.
There were no bloody battles, no
blasted friendships, and no one
injured. All was carried on in
the most amicable manner possible, bringing out much in the
characters of many students,
which had hitherto lain dormant,
and cementing closer the friendships between members of the two
classes. '

0. D. K. ELECTS NEW MEMBERS
Public Initiation Next Friday, May 7th
--Heiner. to Head Honorary.
Fraternity Next Year.

At the last meeting of Omicron
Delta Kappa, several neW members were elected to that honorary
society. The, public initiation of
the men chosen will be held at a
mass-meeting on next Friday, May
7. The officers of the society for
next year were chosen at the same
time, as follows:
President—R. Graham Heiner.
Vice - President — Norman C.
Keyes.
Secretary—George Getz.
A circle of 0. D. K. was found- ed at Johns Hopkins in 1917. The
society was originated at Washington and Lee University. Ours
is the second, of the chapters,'
which now number four: The
purpose is two-fold: The recognition of those who have attained
distinction in collegiate activities, and the forniation of a body
which will support the best efforts for the good of the University and set an example of leadership. It ,includes in its scope all
phases of college life, and unites
the various interests of the campus. The five divisions which
are the basis of the choice of members are these:
1. Scholarship or marked proficiency in one or more collegiate
departments.
2. Athletics, both local and
inter-collegiate.
3. Social leadership, including
conspicuous service to the institution.
4. Literary societies and intercollegiate contests.
5. Publications.
The recognition of a man's leadership in college life by election
to 0. D. K. may be given as early
as the sophomore year. In addition to the undergraduates, there
are a number of faculty members.
Tennis Team Meets Hard Luck.

The tennis team has so far
fared very badly, having lost to
Swarthmore, Camp Humphries
and Washington and Lee, tied
Tufts and defeated Richmond College. Four matches only were
played against Tufts, rain preventing the playing of the remaining two. Only four matches were
played against Richmond College,
since some of the Hopkins men
were lost, but fortunately all of
these were won by the Hopkins
men, thus giving them the contest.
The game with Navy, scheduled
for April 28, had to be cancelled
on account of the weather. The
team is scheduled to play Camp
Humphries at Washington again,
and it is probable that they will
be able to retrieve their defeat
of last week.

plans to send the 'varsity baseball
nine to Japan during the summer
months.

Lieutenant -Colonel Gary, a
close friend and comrade of Captain Ellis during the war, has
been secured by the commandant
of Hopkins R. 0. T. C. to assist
in the field problems, in preparation for the inspection of the Hopkins battalion,upon its recommendation for a place among the
Colonel
"Distinguished Ten."
Gary saw a year's service in
France on the staff of General
Pershing. He had a ample opportunity to study the tactics and
maneuvers of the best officers in
the American Army. While in
France, Colonel Gary outlined
and developed a mode of taking
or destroying strong points. He
has-come to give Hopkins the full
benefit of his knowledge.
Last Tuesday, Colonel Gary explained the theoretical maneuvers
in the taking of a machine gun
nest. For the purpose of instruction, he used a reproduction on
the blackboard of the map recently drawn by a detachment of the
Sophomore Class in topography.
This map of the Lake Montebello
region of Baltimore will be used
by the inspectors in directing the
maneuvers on the day of the inspection.
Ot Saturday morning the entire
battalion turned out under full
equipment to get its first lesson
in the practical application ,of
the attack on a fortified position.
Two automobiles were used to
carry out the machine gun squad
with their equipment, which was
set up and artificially concealed
before the arrival of the three
companies. The entire group was
divided into two bodies, and the
conditions of the situation explained.
The problem was a difficult one,
for by 10 minutes after the assault had begun the attacking
forces would have been destroyed,
but since the machine gunners
were true friends, their lives were
spared and action continued. After the removal of four nests, located in various corners of the
sector, the action was judged finished, and recall was sounded.
Colonel Gary discussed the
problem as he saw it and as it
was attacked by us. Although
many corrections are to be made
and several things to be learned,
he said that for the first attempt,
very good generalship had been
shown, and with more practice he
believed that the battalion could
prove its merit to the inspectors
and obtain a position on the distinguished list.
I fear I'll never, never,
Be a big "he" male,
'Cause I can't light matches
With my right thumb nail.

.Social Science Club Notice.

At the meeting of the Social
Science Club, held last Friday,
April 23, a very interesting paper
was read by -Mr. Bramble on John
Maynard Keynes' book, "The Economic Consequences of the War."
After the paper, the meeting was
devoted to general discussion of
the subject and of the future
plans of the club. It was decided
to devote the next meeting to the
adoption of the constitution and
to the election of officers for the
coming year. It is absolutely vital
that all members be present at
this meeting, and the officers take
this opportunity to impress it
upon all those who were not present last Friday. The schedule of
the club for the rest of the year
includes a lecture, on May 11, by
John Spargo, an event which is
sure to redound greatly to the
credit of the club.
R. 0. T. C. Lecture.

Brigadier-General Swift, U. S.
A., who was head of the American
mission to Italy and is at present
head of the War College at Washington, gave an interesting illustrated lecture last week in the
Civil Engineering Building for
the R: 0. T. C. unit. His subject
was "America's Participation in
the World War." Among the
interesting facts brought out by
General Swift were the reasons
why Neuf Chateau was chosen as
the point of - concentration of
• American fighting troops in
France. "First," he said, "Neuf
. Chateau was the strongest hostile
point; second, the Allies were unable to take it; third, its capture
meant more to the Allies than any
other point." Seventeen lantern
slides of the German offensives of
1918 were shown, and. the lecture
ended with moving pictures of
American troops in action.

Twenty-five minutes was the total time allowed each speaker in
which to deliver both his set speech
and rebuttal. The judges were:
Dr. W. W. Willoughby, Dr. J. C.
French, Dr. H. C. Lancaster, Dr.
R. B. Roulston and Dr. W. 0.
Weyforth, all of the Hopkins faculty. Dr. French acted also as
presiding officer. Several piano
and banjo selections were given
during the program.
On the same night that this debate was held at Homewood, the
two Hopkins teams were in the
South. The negative team, composed of Goetz and Berkowitz,
met and defeated the Washington
and Lee representatives at Chapel
Hill, N. C., receiving the unani-

mous vote of the five judges.
The affirmative team (Lewin
and Gould), however, were not so
fortunate. Debating against the
North Carolina men at Lexington,
Va., the Hopkins representatives
lost the decision; 3 to 2. The
subject was the same in all three
debates.

the first day of the Penn Relays.
That all three of these men are
fine runners was proven last fall
in the Inter-collegiate Cross.
Championships, and
Country
more recently in the Michigan'Cornell dual meet, where they all
placed in the mile run.

Yale has joined the movement
to bring down the present high
cost of clothing by holding "Old
Clothes Day" in the Sheffield Scientific School. Any man wearing a new suit of clothes will be
guilty of a serious breach of social
etiquette.
While the campaign will not
go to the same extremes that it
has in the South, the Old Clothes
Club believes "that the price of
suits would be materially lowered
if every man in the university
were to wear out his old clothes
instead of selling them at ridiculously low prices." Sweaters,
coats and trousers of a different
material, army shoes or bedroom
slippers, and last year's hats constitute the proper attire for men.
However, no .embargo on clean

Prov s No Match for Hopkins' Lacrosse
Team in Passing or Stick Work—
Score, 13-0—Silberstein, Bauernschmidt and Defandorf Star.

Combined Musical and Glee Clubs Render Attractive Program at C.E.Hall
Friday Night—A Fo,mal Dance
Was Held After the Concet t.

Defeats the Hopkins Affirmative Team,
and the Washington and Lee
Negative Team.

The Rutgers lacrosse team
proved to be no match for the
Hopkins twelve, the latter scoring an easy victory last Saturday,
13 to. 0. The visitors' attack was
very poor, while their passing and
stickwork seemed equally bad.
They showed plenty of fight, however, and were always in the
game.
Silberstein, who took Stuart's
place, was the scoring star of the
game, with four goals to his
credit, while Defandorf and Bauernschmidt were not far 'behind
him, each .scoring three times.
"Bobby" Hoffman's work was
also particularly good, since he
stopped many rushes down the
field, which seemed sure to reach
the close ,defense.
During the first half, the Rutgers team made the play comparatively close, and only three scores
were made, by Hinrichs, Hoffman
and Silberstein: Hopkins started
the second period with a rush, and
scored continually, so that when
the smoke cleared away 10 markers had been, chalked up. The
home team used many.substitutes
(luring the latter part of the game,
but seemed to be able to score as
well as ever.
The Hopkins team showed a decided return to first-class form in
this game, and were far superior
to their opponents in passing and
teamwork, a department in which
Rutgers„was noticeably lacking.
As Rufiers . played a very close
game with Swarthmore last week,
Hopkins shiyind meet- with success
in her Inter-collegiate League
games. .
The brilliant vermilion jerseys
and stockings of the New Jersey
men made the game a •pretty one
to watch, while Feirer, Rutgers'
.chunky goal, furnished much
amusement by the speed and manner in which he got the ball away
from the net.

Before a disappointingly small
audience, the debating team of the
University of North Carolina was
awarded the victory over the
Washington and Lee representatives on Saturday evening in the
Civil Engineering Hall, by a
unanimous vote of.the five judges.
The subject for debate was: "A
system of universal military
training for young men should
be established by the United
States." The North Carolinians
supported the affirmative of this
question.
Daniel L. Grant, first affirmat ive speaker, pointed out the fact
that other great nations of the
world are increasing their armaments, and that therefore in order to retain her place as a leader and to secure herself against
future invasion,, _America must
adopt an effective method of constructing a powerful military machine.
Robert B. Gwynn,second affirmative speaker, presented a large
number of. historical instances to
show the inadequacy of the voluntary system of maintaining our,
armies. He also outlined a system of universal milit6ry training which, to his mind, would
prove most efficacious in the Unit-,
ed States. This system, according
to the figures ,whlch he presented,
would aptually cost less than the
maintenance of our present small
standing army.
Carl A.Voss, first speaker for
Washipton and Leç,jointed out
that -the affirmative mnst..Arst
prove that the voluntary system
of maintaining our armies has
some incurable and inherent defects, and then, in addition to
lit is, must show that the adoption
of a system of universal training
is the best method of establishing
an effective military organization.
lie then attempted to prove that
many defects of the present system had already been corrected,
and that the remaining defects
could likewise be remedied. Mr.
Poss delivered a well-prepared
e eh in a clear, convincing manlier.
Walter E. Smith, last speaker
for the negative, objected to the
universal military training plan
on the grounds that it would increase taxes, that it was through
this very system that Bismarck
had molded Germany into a highly militaristic nation, that military life is morally degrading,

The concert given by the combined Johns Hopkins Orchestra
and Choral Society on April 27
was a marked success for the
Johns Hopkins Musical Association. The audience overflowed
the seating space, and many stood
throughout the entire performance.
A particularly interesting feature was the first appearance of
the Johns Hopkins Choral Society, which rendered admirably
"Hiawatha's Wedding Feast,"
from Coleridge-Taylor's famous
cantata. The ensemble tone was
of agreeable quality, and the technical difficulties of the work were
skilfully handled. Mr. Bochau is
to be congratulated upon the excellent results achieved in so
short a time with a new organization.
The orchestra first played two
movements from Beethoven's second symphony with surprising
facility and smoothness, and was
later heard in an arrangement of
Bruch's "Kol Nidrei" and Bendel's "Snow White." The cello
silo of this piece was presented
by Helen Broemer, accompanied
by Susan Haury.
The present membership of the
orchestra is 85, including professional musicians assisting for
this concert, and 80 per cent. of
the orchestra amateurs, among
them some graduates and undergraduate students of the University and members of the faculty,
and many well-known outside musicians, both men and women.
Those desiring to join the orchestra should make application
to Mr. Bochau at 304 East North
avenue.

among universities and colleges
throughout the country. Dartmouth freshmen recently took
these, and the results were as follows: The highest grade obtained
was 203 out of a possible 212. The
lowest grade was 70. The average for 636 students was 148.35.
The army and navy average for
these same tests was but 53.

BALTIMORE, MD,

MAY 3, 1920

The little affair of last week
was a fitting answer to the editorial in the issue of April 27.
The "Banquet Scene" was the
first sign of life which Hopkins
has displayed in quite a while,
but it shows that there is a little
spark still burning, and that it
can, upon occasion, flare up into
a regular flame.
Let us hope that the past outburst of "pep" will spread into
more appropriate channels—into
the backing up of the athletic and
non-athletic activities of the University. If such spirit were shown
more often, the populace of Baltimore would not be so surprised,
and other colleges would realize
that we have an undergraduate
student body which is interested
in the welfare of Hopkins.
The sole drawback to the whole
affair that THE NEWS-LETTER observed was the unfortunate'and,
for the most part, erroneous publicity which was accorded it.
There were no bloody battles, no
blasted friendships, and no one
injured. All was carried on in
the most amicable manner possible, bringing out much in the
characters of many students,
which had hitherto lain dormant,
and cementing closer the friendships between members of the two
classes. '

0. D. K. ELECTS NEW MEMBERS
Public Initiation Next Friday, May 7th
--Heiner. to Head Honorary.
Fraternity Next Year.

At the last meeting of Omicron
Delta Kappa, several neW members were elected to that honorary
society. The, public initiation of
the men chosen will be held at a
mass-meeting on next Friday, May
7. The officers of the society for
next year were chosen at the same
time, as follows:
President—R. Graham Heiner.
Vice - President — Norman C.
Keyes.
Secretary—George Getz.
A circle of 0. D. K. was found- ed at Johns Hopkins in 1917. The
society was originated at Washington and Lee University. Ours
is the second, of the chapters,'
which now number four: The
purpose is two-fold: The recognition of those who have attained
distinction in collegiate activities, and the forniation of a body
which will support the best efforts for the good of the University and set an example of leadership. It ,includes in its scope all
phases of college life, and unites
the various interests of the campus. The five divisions which
are the basis of the choice of members are these:
1. Scholarship or marked proficiency in one or more collegiate
departments.
2. Athletics, both local and
inter-collegiate.
3. Social leadership, including
conspicuous service to the institution.
4. Literary societies and intercollegiate contests.
5. Publications.
The recognition of a man's leadership in college life by election
to 0. D. K. may be given as early
as the sophomore year. In addition to the undergraduates, there
are a number of faculty members.
Tennis Team Meets Hard Luck.

The tennis team has so far
fared very badly, having lost to
Swarthmore, Camp Humphries
and Washington and Lee, tied
Tufts and defeated Richmond College. Four matches only were
played against Tufts, rain preventing the playing of the remaining two. Only four matches were
played against Richmond College,
since some of the Hopkins men
were lost, but fortunately all of
these were won by the Hopkins
men, thus giving them the contest.
The game with Navy, scheduled
for April 28, had to be cancelled
on account of the weather. The
team is scheduled to play Camp
Humphries at Washington again,
and it is probable that they will
be able to retrieve their defeat
of last week.

plans to send the 'varsity baseball
nine to Japan during the summer
months.

Lieutenant -Colonel Gary, a
close friend and comrade of Captain Ellis during the war, has
been secured by the commandant
of Hopkins R. 0. T. C. to assist
in the field problems, in preparation for the inspection of the Hopkins battalion,upon its recommendation for a place among the
Colonel
"Distinguished Ten."
Gary saw a year's service in
France on the staff of General
Pershing. He had a ample opportunity to study the tactics and
maneuvers of the best officers in
the American Army. While in
France, Colonel Gary outlined
and developed a mode of taking
or destroying strong points. He
has-come to give Hopkins the full
benefit of his knowledge.
Last Tuesday, Colonel Gary explained the theoretical maneuvers
in the taking of a machine gun
nest. For the purpose of instruction, he used a reproduction on
the blackboard of the map recently drawn by a detachment of the
Sophomore Class in topography.
This map of the Lake Montebello
region of Baltimore will be used
by the inspectors in directing the
maneuvers on the day of the inspection.
Ot Saturday morning the entire
battalion turned out under full
equipment to get its first lesson
in the practical application ,of
the attack on a fortified position.
Two automobiles were used to
carry out the machine gun squad
with their equipment, which was
set up and artificially concealed
before the arrival of the three
companies. The entire group was
divided into two bodies, and the
conditions of the situation explained.
The problem was a difficult one,
for by 10 minutes after the assault had begun the attacking
forces would have been destroyed,
but since the machine gunners
were true friends, their lives were
spared and action continued. After the removal of four nests, located in various corners of the
sector, the action was judged finished, and recall was sounded.
Colonel Gary discussed the
problem as he saw it and as it
was attacked by us. Although
many corrections are to be made
and several things to be learned,
he said that for the first attempt,
very good generalship had been
shown, and with more practice he
believed that the battalion could
prove its merit to the inspectors
and obtain a position on the distinguished list.
I fear I'll never, never,
Be a big "he" male,
'Cause I can't light matches
With my right thumb nail.

.Social Science Club Notice.

At the meeting of the Social
Science Club, held last Friday,
April 23, a very interesting paper
was read by -Mr. Bramble on John
Maynard Keynes' book, "The Economic Consequences of the War."
After the paper, the meeting was
devoted to general discussion of
the subject and of the future
plans of the club. It was decided
to devote the next meeting to the
adoption of the constitution and
to the election of officers for the
coming year. It is absolutely vital
that all members be present at
this meeting, and the officers take
this opportunity to impress it
upon all those who were not present last Friday. The schedule of
the club for the rest of the year
includes a lecture, on May 11, by
John Spargo, an event which is
sure to redound greatly to the
credit of the club.
R. 0. T. C. Lecture.

Brigadier-General Swift, U. S.
A., who was head of the American
mission to Italy and is at present
head of the War College at Washington, gave an interesting illustrated lecture last week in the
Civil Engineering Building for
the R: 0. T. C. unit. His subject
was "America's Participation in
the World War." Among the
interesting facts brought out by
General Swift were the reasons
why Neuf Chateau was chosen as
the point of - concentration of
• American fighting troops in
France. "First," he said, "Neuf
. Chateau was the strongest hostile
point; second, the Allies were unable to take it; third, its capture
meant more to the Allies than any
other point." Seventeen lantern
slides of the German offensives of
1918 were shown, and. the lecture
ended with moving pictures of
American troops in action.

Twenty-five minutes was the total time allowed each speaker in
which to deliver both his set speech
and rebuttal. The judges were:
Dr. W. W. Willoughby, Dr. J. C.
French, Dr. H. C. Lancaster, Dr.
R. B. Roulston and Dr. W. 0.
Weyforth, all of the Hopkins faculty. Dr. French acted also as
presiding officer. Several piano
and banjo selections were given
during the program.
On the same night that this debate was held at Homewood, the
two Hopkins teams were in the
South. The negative team, composed of Goetz and Berkowitz,
met and defeated the Washington
and Lee representatives at Chapel
Hill, N. C., receiving the unani-

mous vote of the five judges.
The affirmative team (Lewin
and Gould), however, were not so
fortunate. Debating against the
North Carolina men at Lexington,

Yale has joined the movement
to bring down the present high
cost of clothing by holding "Old
Clothes Day" in the Sheffield Scientific School. Any man wearing a new suit of clothes will be
guilty of a serious breach of social
etiquette.
While the campaign will not
go to the same extremes that it
has in the South, the Old Clothes
Club believes "that the price of
suits would be materially lowered
if every man in the university
were to wear out his old clothes
instead of selling them at ridiculously low prices." Sweaters,
coats and trousers of a different
material, army shoes or bedroom
slippers, and last year's hats constitute the proper attire for men.
However, no .embargo on clean
linen is in effpct.
